prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC 1332
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observation of CO(2-1) emission from the circumnuclear disk in NGC 1332, at 0.04 arcsec resolution, in order to measure the mass of the central supermassive black hole.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Based on our experience working with our Cycle 2 data and our dynamical modeling, velocity channels of 20 km/s are sufficient to map the disk's kinematics accurately. The disk emission spans a full velocity width of 1000 km/s (i.e., +-500 km/s relative to systemic), and 20 km/s channels provide a total of 50 channels across the velocity structure of the disk. We will use spectral averaging to 5 km/s to lower the data rate while still retaining the ability to recalibrate the data to channels narrower than 20 km/s if the S/N allows. In our Cycle 2 data, at a given spatial position within the disk, the line profiles have FWHM ranging from about 20 km/s (at large radius) up to about 200 km/s near the disk center.

As described in the proposal justification, our angular resolution requirement is to obtain at least 10 independent resolution elements across the BH radius of influence, even if the BH mass is as low as the 1-sigma lower bound from Rusli et al. (2011), equal to 1.25x10^9 solar masses. This sets a requirement of 0.04" resolution. Crucially, this very high resolution will resolve the circumnuclear disk's spatial structure on the scale of the BH radius of influence even along the disk's minor-axis direction. This is critically important since the disk is very highly inclined: the exquisite 0.04" resolution means that the major-axis velocity profile of the disk will not be significantly contaminated by low-velocity emission originating from along the minor axis direction of the disk. Our simulations demonstrate that resolution of 0.04" will be sufficient to clearly resolve the central Keplerian velocity upturn in the disk, providing a spectacularly clear detection of the central mass.
We note that, even if the BH mass is as low as the value found by Humphrey et al (2009) from modeling the hydrostatic equilibrium of the X-ray emitting gaseous halo of NGC 1332, our ALMA data will still resolve the BH sphere of influence very well, with ~3 independent resolution elements across r_g. However, the higher BH mass measured by Rusli et al. is a more robust measurement, since this measurement was carried out using high-resolution VLT adaptive optics data, with several times higher angular resolution than the X-ray data used by Humphrey et al.
At the proposed 0.04" resolution, the largest angular scale that can be recovered is 0.45 arcsec. This is approximately equal to the radius of influence of the black hole itself, so our observations will fully and accurately map the kinematics within the radius of influence; this is our primary goal. Furthermore, we note that information on larger angular scales will not be entirely resolved out due to the very large velocity gradient across the disk's surface, spanning a full width of approximately 1000 km/s. We will combine our high-resolution data with the lower-resolution Cycle 2 data already in hand so that our dynamical models can be fit to the entire spatial structure of the disk simultaneously, from deep within the black hole's sphere of influence out to the outer edge of the disk at r=2.2 arcsec.

We base our sensitivity requirement on measurements from our Cycle 2 observation, with 0.3" resolution (FWHM) and 0.07" pixel size. The most important consideration for this program is to obtain a highly significant detection of the high-velocity emission in the innermost, Keplerian region of the disk. In the Cycle 2 data we detect CO flux at velocities up to +-500 km/s relative to the systemic velocity. In the highest-velocity channel exhibiting detected flux, with a channel width of 20 km/s, our Cycle 2 data exhibits an unresolved source with a brightness of 25 mJy/beam.
We use this measured flux to estimate the expected flux in a beam with 0.04" FWHM. The key consideration is the spatial distribution of this high-velocity flux, which is spatially unresolved in our 0.3" data. We use our dynamical modeling apparatus to examine the expected _intrinsic_ spatial distribution of the flux in a 20 km/s wide channel at a velocity of +500 km/s relative to the systemic velocity. We find that the spatial region emitting this high-velocity flux is essentially a linear feature extending along the disk major axis, with a width so narrow that it is unresolved even at 0.04" resolution. Since the intrinsic source structure is an unresolved "line" of flux, the brightness per synthesized beam will scale with the beam radius (as opposed to scaling with beam area if it was a source with uniform surface brightness over a 2-dimensional area). Thus, we expect our high-resolution 0.04" observations to detect a brightness of approximately 3 mJy per synthesized beam for the high-velocity flux in a 20 km/s channel. Our minimal goal is to achieve S/N=10 per spatial resolution element per velocity channel for this high-velocity emission so that we can map the spatial and velocity structure accurately. We choose an rms sensitivity of 0.25 mJy/beam, which provides a nominal S/N of 12 for our expected high-velocity flux, allowing a small additional margin should the spatial distribution of the flux be slightly more diffuse than we expect based on the dynamical model fits to our Cycle 2 data. With this requirement, our on-source exposure time is 1.86 hours.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: In Cycle 2 we began a program to identify optimal targets for measurement of the masses of supermassive black holes in early-type galaxies by mapping the kinematics of circumnuclear molecular disks. Our recently obtained Cycle 2 observations of NGC 1332, at 0.3" resolution, clearly demonstrate that its disk is in near-perfect circular rotation, and we detect high-velocity emission (up to +-500 km/s) from rotating gas within the black hole's dynamical radius of influence. However, the Cycle 2 data are not sufficient to determine the black hole mass accurately, due to the degeneracy between the black hole and the spatially extended stellar mass distribution. Here, we propose to obtain new CO(2-1) observations at 0.04" resolution which will resolve the black hole's dynamical sphere of influence exquisitely well, enabling us to determine the black hole mass accurately via dynamical modeling of the disk rotation. The proposed observations will represent a spectacular showcase for ALMA's revolutionary high-resolution capabilities, and the new data will have the potential to provide the most accurate mass measurement ever obtained for a very high-mass (~10^9 solar mass) black hole.
